Fix draft frame spec
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/background-color","confidence":90,"prompt":"Let's fix the draft frame spec. Shape is not yet needed. We want Frame and it should be a type not an interface. It should specify only a background color. Renderers should render a 100x100 square of the color. The Generator interface has a single function `frame (time: number): Frame`. Renderer has `render(time: number): void`. It also have `loop(): void` and `stop(): void` to start and stop a render loop. Neither interfaces are generic. Implementations should default time to zero. renderers expect request animation frame support. renderers render a 100x100 square of the background color, and replace it if that is changed. Renderer constructors accept HTML elements of the relevant type."}

nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/background-color","confidence":85,"prompt":"Create a test app so that we can visually confirm rendering is correct. It does not need to be a fully-fledged npm package, but it can be if that's best. Make it as simple as possible, with as few dependencies as possible. We want a page that displays the matrix of generator/renderer combinations. Each combination should render the same view, which for now is simply a background color. There should be an input field on the page to change the background color, all of the combinations should update when that happens. We need a way for claude code to run the app, inspect the page, and verify that the page is as expected. Examine the options for that, we can install any new claude code plugins if required."}

Integrate sub-agents into workflow
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/circles","confidence":90,"prompt":"You are correct. First, though, we need to ensure that we have captured our inspriration for each generator correctly. One generator takes inspiration from p5.js where cilent code supplies a sketch that uses the generator API once per frame to specify what should be rendered. The other generator takes inspiration from three.js (and others) where client code constructs a scene graph of elements in the scene, then modifies it when the render should look different. I want to make sure we respect these considerations.

We can use sub-agents to look after each package. What do you think? There is an example from deciduous that I saw recently. The relevant fragment in the CLAUDE.md file is here (https://github.com/notactuallytreyanastasio/deciduous/blob/main/CLAUDE.md#subagents---domain-specific-context). It refers to an agents.toml file here (https://github.com/notactuallytreyanastasio/deciduous/blob/main/.claude/agents.toml). Tell me whether this is a suitable way to use sub-agents in claude code. If so, we should:
- Update the README files in each of our packages to capture the design considerations, constraints, inspiration and driver
- Write a agent spec for each package
- Update CLAUDE.md to INSIST that claude code uses the correct agent whenever we design changes for a package, make edits to the package, or review changes.

I will want you to propose the spec and instructions for each sub-agent. I may want to iterate, add or remove instructions - it will be easier for me if I can look at a proposal for each.

That's the next goal: integrating sub-agents into our workflow"}

nodes.title: Choose pattern for color properties in Frame spec
Stroke width not supported - using fixed 5 units/pixels
Implementing line rendering
Line rendering working - all 4 renderers produce identical output
File edits must use Task agents - updated CLAUDE.md with mandatory sub-agent workflow
Committed line rendering and sub-agent workflow
Frame spec is an IR - optimize for validation simplicity, not human readability. Generators provide ergonomic APIs, renderers pre-process as needed.
Flat: each shape has fill/stroke/strokeWidth properties directly. Simple but verbose, repetitive when shapes share styles.
Nested groups: shapes nested under style groups that provide fill/stroke. More compact for shared styles, but complex typedef, draw order requires careful nesting.
Global materials + references: Frame has materials table, shapes reference by ID. Like glTF. Compact but two structures (materials table + content tree).

Pure tree with ancestor references: single tree, root is complete material, all other materials are partial with required ref to ancestor. Shapes have no material properties. Validation is single-pass top-to-bottom.
Analogous systems: CSS (cascade + inheritance), USD (composition arcs), glTF (material references), SVG (defs + inheritance). Pure tree model closest to CSS cascading.
Groups not needed in pure tree model - Material nodes provide both style inheritance AND tree structure. Groups only needed later for transforms.

Ancestor-only references: prevents cycles by construction, enables single-pass validation, shared materials must be hoisted to common ancestor. Trade-off: sibling branches cannot share materials defined in one branch.
Pure tree model: RootMaterial has all properties required (fill, stroke, strokeWidth), no ref. ChildMaterial has all properties optional, ref required and must be ancestor ID, id required and unique.
Verbosity trade-off: single-shape overrides require wrapper Material node. Acceptable for IR - generators provide ergonomic APIs. Future optimization pass could compact frames.
Generator implications: p5.js push/pop maps to entering/exiting Material nodes. fill()/stroke() changes require new sibling Material branch. Generator must build tree, not flat list.
Tree structure: heterogeneous types vs generic node with payload
Heterogeneous types: Material/Transform have children, Shapes are leaves. Type-safe (shapes can't have children at compile time), but traversal needs per-type handling.
Generic node: all nodes have payload + optional children. Uniform traversal, but allows semantically invalid trees (circle with children). Must validate at runtime.
Selected heterogeneous types for now. Simpler, type-safe, sufficient for materials + shapes. Revisit when transforms land if pattern feels wrong.
Implement Material-based Frame spec with validation

{"branch":"feat/lines-color-and-fill","confidence":90,"prompt":"I think we should proceed. However, there are number of things we have talked about:

- we will need to inject validation into the process! So far, we have said that renderers can assume frames are valid. But generators should not validate their own outputs. Perhaps for now we just put validation into the renderers.
- generators now have more work to do
- as do renderers

There is a lot of work there. We may need multiple sessions."}

Add transform support to Frame spec
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/transforms","confidence":90,"prompt":"I have some opinions. It would be good to have them challenged/validated.
- Opinion 1: Transform nodes are distinct in the Frame Spec, and sit in the tree in the same way that Materials do. There is no need to combine these two concerns.
- Opinion 2: There is no need for an "inheritance" mechanism as we had for materials. Every transform is complete and affects all of its children. Transforms **accumulate** when rendering, as a consumer of the generator APIs would expect.
- Opinion 3: translate, rotate and scale are generator API concerns. We do not **necessarily** need to reflect that in the Frame Spec, which is supposed to be an easy to validate and parse/traverse, machine-readable data structure. It should also be compact, where possible.

On opinion 3:
- this suggests that we could be maximally-explicit in the frame spec. Transform node is a matrix (affine transformation) that can capture any translation, rotation, scale or combination.
- that may, however, be verbose and inefficient from the perspective of size of the frame spec data structure. A translation can be expressed as metadata plus two numbers. But a matrix will require more data.
- perhaps for simple transformations, we can support more "compact" representations later - as an optimisation

Please dispatch task agents to examine different existing mechanisms. Three.js and p5.js are obvious choices, but there will be others so search for them first. Remember: our first task is to design the correct **intermediate representation** in the frame spec. For this, we need to capture the needs of a scene graph - so we may be driven by the needs of the renderers. It is **not** the same thing at the opinionated client APIs offered by generators."}

nodes.title: Choose transform representation for Frame IR
Matrix-only: 6-value 2D affine matrix [a,b,c,d,e,f]
TRS decomposed: separate translate, rotate, scale properties
Dual representation: TRS for API, matrix for IR (like three.js)
Operation stack: ordered list of operations (like USD xformOps)
Discriminated union: matrix OR compact forms (translate/rotate/scale)

Three.js: stores TRS properties (position, quaternion, scale) + computes matrix. matrixWorld = parentMatrixWorld  localMatrix. Uses 4x4 Matrix4 internally. Decomposition has known issues with non-uniform scale.

p5.js: immediate mode with matrix stack. 2D uses 6-element [a,b,c,d,e,f], WebGL uses 16-element 4x4. push()/pop() save/restore entire state including transforms. translate/rotate/scale multiply current matrix.

SVG: transform attribute supports both matrix(a,b,c,d,e,f) AND decomposed (translate, rotate, scale). Can mix freely. consolidate() merges to single matrix. Nested transforms accumulate via post-multiplication.
Canvas 2D: native 6-value affine matrix [a,b,c,d,e,f]. setTransform() replaces, transform() multiplies. save()/restore() manages state stack. getTransform() returns DOMMatrix snapshot.
glTF: allows TRS OR matrix (not both). TRS required for animation (can't interpolate arbitrary matrices). Composition order TRS. Matrix must be decomposable to TRS (no shear).
USD: operation stacks with explicit xformOpOrder. Most flexible - supports translate, rotate, scale, orient (quaternion), transform (matrix), shear. Enables non-destructive editing.
Lottie: decomposed properties only (anchor, position, scale, rotation). Animation-first design with keyframe support. Composition order implicit from After Effects.
RealityKit: TRS struct with SIMD types. Quaternion-only rotation. Entity-component architecture. Designed for runtime performance and animation interpolation.
VALIDATED: Transform accumulation (not inheritance) is universal. All systems use matrix multiplication: worldMatrix = parentWorld  localMatrix. No override mechanism like materials.
VALIDATED: Matrix as canonical form for render-focused IR. Both Canvas (6-value native) and SVG (matrix() attribute) consume matrices directly. TRS only needed if animation interpolation required.
NUANCED: Transform nodes distinct from Materials - validated for IR design, but most systems treat transform as node property not separate type. Renderers will extract matrix and apply to context.
2D affine matrix format: [a,b,c,d,e,f] representing |a c e| |b d f| |0 0 1|. Point (x,y) transforms to (ax+cy+e, bx+dy+f). Identity is [1,0,0,1,0,0].
Design decision: Transform node has NO id attribute (unlike Materials). Transforms don't need references - they just compose during traversal.
Design decision: Transforms and Materials nest flexibly and arbitrarily. Renderer's job to separate concerns during traversal (save/restore context appropriately).
Design decision: No compact identity representation. To express identity, simply omit the Transform node entirely.

Optimization strategy: Generators create output quickly without optimization. Post-processor can detect sequentially-nested transforms and combine into single matrix. Safe transformation - matrix multiplication is associative.
Selected: Matrix-only Transform nodes with 6-value 2D affine matrix. No id, flexible nesting with Materials, accumulate via multiplication. Compact forms deferred as future optimization.

nodes.title: Coordinate system origin and orientation

Scaling modes: fit (letterbox), fill (crop), stretch. Coordinate space defined in Frame spec (viewBox/extents).
Resize handling: renderer queries element size on every render() call. No observers, no caching - fresh mapping each frame.
CORRECTION: scaleMode is in Frame spec (not renderer). Extents defined as halfWidth/halfHeight from center origin (not min/max which would be redundant/inconsistent).

It's about rendering images into our little test-app. A library like p5.js can fetch an image from a URL, and render it (or part of it) onto the canvas.\n\np5.js uses the canvas API or webgl to do this, if I remember correctly. Is there support for rendering images (or parts of them) in SVG and/or canvas API? Dispatch task agents to find out"}

nodes.title: Canvas: drawImage() with 9-param overload supports cropping (sprite sheets). ImageBitmap is optimal format with explicit .close() for memory control.
SVG: <image> element with clipPath for cropping. Blob URLs avoid double-fetch. Must revoke URLs manually.
CORS applies to both: Canvas gets 'tainted' (can't read pixels), SVG won't load cross-origin without headers.
Design general resource management system (images first, then video, shaders)
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/images","confidence":90,"prompt":"Images, in my mind, will be our first example of using *resources* - which are referenced in the frame spec but loaded by a renderer. We may later have other examples of resources (eg video). And some future renderers will have resources required simply to function - for example a webgpu renderer will need to examine the frame spec and determine whether new shader/pipeline resources are required.\n\nSo I'd like a strong model for resources in general - potentially one that can be shared between renderers."}

nodes.title: Choose resource loading strategy
Native browser loading: rely on <image> href, HTMLImageElement natural loading
Managed resources: fetch blobs ourselves, renderer-specific post-processing, explicit disposal
Selected: Managed resources - consistent behavior across renderers, explicit memory control, future-proof for WebGPU
Resource tiers: required (blocking), optional (skip/placeholder), defaulting (fallback until ready). V1 implements blocking only.
Architecture: Renderers extract ResourceRequirements from Frame, hand to ResourceManager, await response. ResourceManager handles fetch/cache.
Post-processing injection: ResourceManager<T> with ResourcePostProcessor<T> interface. Canvas injects blobImageBitmap, SVG injects blobblobURL, WebGPU would inject blobGPUTexture.
Disposal: diff-based (resource present last frame but not this frame  dispose). Pre-destroy callbacks paired with post-processing. Renderer.destroy() cleans up all.
V1 simplicity: each renderer owns its ResourceManager (no sharing). Just url in ResourceRequirement. Browser handles HTTP caching.
Implementing V1 resource management system

Examining resource deduplication for multiple image nodes
Deduplication working correctly: URL-keyed Map in ResourceManager means same URL fetched once, cached, reused across frames and across multiple Image nodes in same Frame
Dedup mechanism: extractResourceUrls() returns Set (unique URLs), getResource() caches by URL key, multiple Image nodes share same fetched resource
No cross-renderer dedup: each renderer owns its ResourceManager. In test-app with 4 renderers, same image fetched 4x. Acceptable for V1 - browser HTTP cache mitigates.
In-flight dedup: ResourceState tracks 'loading' with shared Promise. Concurrent getResource() calls for same URL await same fetch, no race conditions.
Resource deduplication review complete: V1 implementation correct. URL-keyed cache provides per-renderer dedup. Cross-renderer sharing deferred (browser cache sufficient).
API design wrong: current design has renderer call markNeeded(), then getResource() per URL, then pruneUnused(). Too many touchpoints, leaky abstraction.
Correct API: renderer generates single resource requirements spec from Frame, hands to ResourceManager ONCE, awaits response with all processed resources. Prune happens internally before return.
Fix ResourceManager API: single method, single call per frame
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/images","confidence":90,"prompt":"I'm looking at the resource manager API. It's not what I was hoping for and not what I described. I'd like the renderer to generate a *single* object with the spec for the image resources it need. I hands this *once per frame* to the resource manager. Then awaits the response. The response has all the required/processed resources. Before returning, this method will perform the \"prune\" step.\n\nThe renderer will therefore only use a single API in the resource manager - to get all its resources - and only once per frame."}

nodes.title: Implementing single-method ResourceManager API
ResourceManager API refactored: single resolveFrame(urls) method. Renderers use one call per frame. 187 tests pass, all checks pass.
Visual verification passed: Image Transforms and Image Crop scenes render identically across all 4 renderers
Committed ResourceManager API refactor
Examining resource management extensibility
ResourceManager<T> assumes single resource type per renderer - can't manage videos AND images with same instance
extractResourceUrls() tightly coupled to Frame tree - only finds image shapes. Fonts/shaders aren't shapes, need different extraction pattern
Video: feasible now, needs separate VideoManager. HTMLVideoElement for playback, no frame-accurate sync without requestVideoFrameCallback
Shaders: don't fit ResourceManager pattern. Need ShaderRegistry, extend Frame spec with resources section. SVG can't render shaders (renderer asymmetry)
Fonts: don't fit ResourceManager. CSS injection is global side-effect, disposal hard. Need separate FontLoader with pre-load before frame
V2 recommendation: separate manager instances per resource type, extend Frame spec with resources section for non-shape resources, add prefetch/retry APIs
Extensibility review complete: V1 excellent for images (9/10), limited for non-shape resources (4/10). Video feasible now, shaders/fonts need architectural changes
Re-examining extensibility for renderer-internal derived resources (WebGPU pipelines, shaders)
GPU pipelines are DERIVED resources (from Frame shape types), not EXTERNAL resources (fetched). Different lifecycle: expensive to create, cheap to keep, no pruning
ResourceManager pruning is WRONG for pipelines - frame with circles then lines would delete circle pipeline, causing expensive recompilation when circles return
extractShapeTypes(frame) parallels extractResourceUrls(frame) - same tree walk, different collection. Extraction is reusable, caching strategy differs
WebGPU renderers in wild use static pipeline cache (compile at init) or lazy-forever cache. None use pruning resource manager for pipelines
Recommendation: GPUPipelineProvider interface - getPipeline(shapeType), prewarmPipelines(types), destroy(). No pruning, explicit warmup, ~20 lines. Separate from ResourceManager
Corrected analysis: ResourceManager is for EXTERNAL fetched resources. GPU pipelines are DERIVED - need separate GPUPipelineProvider with no-prune, cache-forever semantics
Other WebGPU resources (e.g., canvas-size-dependent textures for selection) need on-demand creation + pruning. Generic infrastructure handling differing cache/prune strategies may be useful - TBD
Make frame clear optional: rename backgroundColor to background, skip clear when absent
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/optional-clear","confidence":85,"prompt":"Yes, the goal is to make the canvas clear optional. And I also want to discover whether we can support the same for SVG rendering. Here is the behavior I want:
- change Frame.backgroundColor to Frame.background
- if it is present, renderers must clear the rendered contents and initially replace them with the correct background color. This is already working
- if it is absent, the rendered contents must remain, and the next frame will be drawn over it

For the canvas renderer, I believe this is not difficult. For the SVG renderer, we need a strategy so that SVG elements do not accumulate - which will happen quickly at, say, 60pfs. Capture the goal please, the investigate whether this is possible in the SVG renderer:
- if the frame is NOT to be cleared
- take a snapshot image of the SVG as it currently is. The size will be the parent element size
- clear the SVG contents
- place snapthot as an image over the full SVG element
- render new elements as normal"}

nodes.title: Investigating SVG snapshot strategy for non-clearing frames
Canvas renderer: making clear optional is trivial - just skip clearRect/fillRect when background absent
SVG snapshot strategy is feasible but ASYNC: XMLSerializer + Blob URL + img.decode() cannot complete synchronously
SVG solution: one-frame-behind snapshot. Frame N snapshot becomes background for frame N+1. Imperceptible at 60fps.
Investigation complete: optional clear is feasible for both renderers. Canvas trivial, SVG uses one-frame-behind snapshot strategy.
Correction: render() is already async (awaits resources). Snapshot can be awaited at START of render, before clear. No frame lag needed.
Corrected SVG flow: 1) render() called 2) if background absent, await snapshot of current content 3) clear SVG 4) insert snapshot as image 5) render new shapes
Implementation approach for optional clear feature
SVG snapshot outside rootGroup, first frame transparent, hide bg rect when undefined
Implementing optional clear feature per approved plan

Optional clear feature implemented: backgroundColor renamed to background, Canvas skips clear when undefined, SVG uses raster snapshot strategy. All 192 tests pass, visual verification confirms accumulating shapes in both renderers.
SVG snapshot accumulates slower than Canvas due to async raster conversion overhead. Visual parity not achieved - SVG shows fewer accumulated shapes. May need optimization or alternative approach.
Achieve visual parity for optional clear feature
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/optional-clear","confidence":85,"prompt":"We want parity. But there are two problems I can see with the optional clear scene. We should investigate each in turn, in this order:\n1. Looking at the working canvas render, I see a difference between the procedural and object scenes. We should determine why this is, and address it.\n2. Yes, the SVG renderer is not working correctly and should be fixed. One thing to check - when we snapshot the SVG in order to preserve the frame, is the previous \"background\" image successfully included in the snapshot? This may be the problem, it may not."}

nodes.title: Investigate procedural vs object scene difference in Canvas renderer
Fix SVG renderer optional clear - check if background image included in snapshot
Object generator scene clears children array and re-adds materials every frame (lines 111-119), unlike procedural which creates fresh Frame IR each call

Object Generator scene sets fill=#000000, stroke=#000000, strokeWidth=1 as scene defaults. Materials only override fill and strokeWidth, not stroke. Result: black stroke visible (strokeWidth inheritance issue) and possibly black fill bleeding through
Fix object generator scene to match procedural material properties
Fixed: removed scene-level defaults, added stroke colors to materials. Canvas Procedural and Object generators now match visually.
Investigating SVG snapshot: checking if previous background image is included when snapshotting

Root cause: SVG snapshot uses blob URL for href. When SVG is serialized and loaded as image, blob URLs from parent document cannot be resolved. Previous snapshot appears blank in new snapshot - chain breaks each frame.
How to fix SVG snapshot accumulation
Use base64 data URL instead of blob URL for snapshot image (Recommended)
Accumulate shapes in DOM instead of snapshotting
Implementing base64 data URL fix for SVG snapshot accumulation
SVG snapshot accumulation fixed. Using base64 data URLs instead of blob URLs. All four renderers (SVG/Canvas x Procedural/Object) now accumulate shapes correctly.
Investigate Canvas+Procedural rendering blue circle with red border (should match SVG)
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/optional-clear","confidence":85,"prompt":"Compare canvas+procedural with canvas+object. Canvas+procedural, after a time, has much less "blue". Assuming the page has only one procedural and one object scene, used with both renderers (is this true?) I'd expect to see the same difference with the SVG render. But I do not.

So, something about the canvas+procedural combination means that the blue dot is different. If I refresh the page, and look at the two procedural scenes:
- the svg renderer renders a blue circle
- the canvas renderer renders a blue circle with a red border

I think this is the issue. Before fixing it, please capture the goal, investigate and tell me the root cause"}

nodes.title: Investigating stroke rendering difference between Canvas and SVG for procedural generator

Root cause: Canvas renderer always calls stroke() even when strokeWidth=0. Canvas API renders 1px hairline at lineWidth=0, while SVG renders nothing at stroke-width=0. Procedural circle 2 has stroke=#ff6b6b (red) inherited from circle 1.
Fix Canvas renderer to skip stroke() when strokeWidth is 0
Fixed: Canvas renderer now skips stroke() when strokeWidth=0. All four renderers show consistent teal/coral coverage.
SVG renderer has visibly lower frame-rate than Canvas for optional clear scene - likely due to base64 data URL snapshot overhead. Not addressing now.
Add rectangle primitive
Implemented rectangle primitive
Rectangle primitive implemented with full parity
Committed rectangle primitive
Add transparency support for stroke and fill colors
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"feat/transparency","confidence":85,"prompt":"I want to add support for transparency in the stroke and fill colors. Please check what's in the codebase already. Examine how p5.js handles this. Look at three.js too. Dispatch tasks to gather information and propose the design, then let me know.\n\nBe sure to capture goals, decisions, options, etc"}

nodes.title: Codebase uses string colors (hex, CSS), no structured type. RGBA/HSLA strings work but no explicit alpha API.
p5.js: alpha is optional 4th parameter on fill()/stroke(). Default 0-255 range. colorMode() adjusts range. color() objects have setAlpha(). Alpha always last param.
three.js: Separates color from opacity. Material has 'opacity' (0-1) + 'transparent:true' flag. Color class is RGB-only, no alpha. Performance-first design.
How to represent alpha/transparency in the spec and APIs
Option A: Separate opacity properties (three.js style) - fillOpacity, strokeOpacity as numbers 0-1
Option B: Alpha as 4th param on fill()/stroke() (p5.js style) - fill(r,g,b,a) or fill('#hex', alpha)
Option C: Keep strings only - document that users pass 'rgba()' CSS strings. No spec changes.
Option D (Recommended): Hybrid - add fillOpacity/strokeOpacity to spec (0-1), procedural API uses optional alpha param, object API uses opacity property
Selected Option C: Keep strings only - no spec changes, users use rgba()/hsla() CSS strings
Add transparency demo to test-app with overlapping shapes testing fill/stroke alpha
Transparency demo working - all shapes (circle, rectangle, line) with transparent fill/stroke render identically across SVG and Canvas
Committed transparency demo
Add mouse/touch interaction support
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/interaction","confidence":85,"prompt":"Thanks. Yes, I want:
- to keep it simple, minimal for now
- mouse and touch interaction only (multiple touches)
- I want interaction support OUT of the generator and renderer packages. Rather, let's create (or find?) a simple utility module that can be used alongside our modules.
- We WILL, however, want to provide some utility functions that all a test-app to take interaction coordinates in "element space" and transform that into the frame space. The frame is specifying extents in x and y - which are then scaled into the canvas or svg. It is the renderers that know about this transform - because they know about:
- the last known size of the HTML element
- the last known extents passed in via a Frame spec

Let's examine the options. p5.js has utility functions injected into the sketch - but I probably don't want that because it's not clear how best to keep that consistent with the object-oriented generator API style. Also it will couple generators to renderers - which is against the design we're working towards here.

So, perhaps it's something like this:
- a 3rd party library or a new medli module that can give you interaction coordinates for touches and mouse
- instantiate that in your app and attach it to your canvas/svg
- a utility function in the Renderer typescript interface - to take that and give you "frame space" coordinates based on the LAST RENDER
- test-apps can take that info, and use it in their procedural (p5 style) sketch, or their OO (three.js style) scene graph

Let's record the goal, decisions to make, options, etc and dispatch tasks to examine feasability and design"}

nodes.title: Choose interaction coordinate source
Choose coordinate transform API placement
3rd party library (e.g., pointer-events polyfill, hammer.js)
New @medli/interaction package
Inline utility in test-app (no package)
Method on Renderer interface: toFrameCoords()
Standalone function taking renderer state
Renderer exposes state, transform computed externally
Native PointerEvent API is sufficient - no library needed
offsetX/offsetY provides element-relative coords directly
Renderer already has computeViewportTransform() - can cache and invert
p5.js hides coords, three.js exposes NDC - medli should provide explicit transform
Use hammer.js - not building custom interaction module
Flexible toFrameCoords API: tuple, array of tuples, Map/Object
Install es-toolkit for data structure utilities (mapValues etc)
Implementing toFrameCoords API and interaction demo
Interaction support implemented - hammer.js tap moves circle to viewport coords
Committed interaction support
Fixed interaction for all four panels
Interaction feature complete - tap works on all 4 panels
Recreate Particle Plotter sketch in medli
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"feat/p5-example","confidence":85,"prompt":"Ok, we are going to have some fun. It will also be a good test of medli so far. I believe we have enough ingredients in place to recreate an example processing (very similar to p5.js) that I have chosen.

The example is here https://openprocessing.org/sketch/751983 but it may be difficult for you to inspect with playwright. Give it a try and let me know.

The sketch uses a particle system. When a user presses the mouse, new particles appear beneath it. The particles are rendered as small circles. The particles then move and change color according to an algorithm, before eventually disappearing. The sketch KEEPS the previous frame, but on each new frame it renders a transparent square over the entire frame. So the particles appear to have a trail, that fades away over time.

There is some help text when there are no particles, which we can completely ignore.

I want to try this with the canvas renderer, which is more performant. And the procedural generator, which is more similar to the processing/p5.js API.

On the page I've linked, there is a button at the top to show the code of the sketch. But I have placed a copy of the code in this file, that we can refer to and them remove at the end packages/test-app/temp-processing-sketch

We will need a new type of test app page, that shows only a single sketch, full screen/page, using the procedural and canvas modules"}

nodes.title: Medli API supports all needed features: line(), strokeWidth(), noBackground() for trails, rectangle() for overlay, p.time for animation
Implemented particle plotter sketch port
Particle plotter working - particles spawn on click/touch, flow according to 12 slope variations, trails fade via transparent overlay
Adding demos dropdown to main test-app page
Added demos dropdown to main page - navigates to full-screen demos
Port Trees01 Processing sketch to medli
medli API sufficient for Trees sketch - HSB via CSS hsla(), map() as helper
Implemented Trees01 port with coordinate system conversion
Trees port working - upward growth, shadow reflections, click to reset
